title: DIY Pain Relief: Your Guide to Over-the-Counter Help

content: We’ve all experienced it – a pounding headache, throbbing joint pain, or menstrual cramps that just won’t quit. Popping an over-the-counter (OTC) medication can seem like the quickest solution to relieving pain and getting on with our day.

I often find that my patients try almost every pain medication OTC before seeing me in the office. It’s hard knowing what to try when there’s an increasing amount of meds available in the pain relief aisle in your local pharmacy.

With that increase in available meds and also in confusion, it's important to go back to the basics. Remember that safety is paramount. Before trying anything new, consult with your doctor. Even commonly used OTCs carry health risks if not taken properly or used without medical oversight.
Have we become too reliant on medication when lifestyle changes and alternative remedies might better address our pain’s underlying causes?

sections.heading: Acetaminophen.
content: This provides pain relief without anti-inflammatory effect. It’s useful for sensitive stomachs, but high doses have the risk of damaging the liver.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These include ibuprofen, aspirin, and naproxen. They inhibit inflammation pathways to treat your pain, fever, and swelling. But they often cause gastrointestinal ulcers or bleeding issues with prolonged high use.

Combo medicines. These include acetaminophen and caffeine. Caffeine enhances the pain-blocking activity of acetaminophen. This can help treat your acute headache, but it doesn’t address underlying migraine causes.
Lifestyle Changes and Natural Remedies to Try First
Before taking an OTC when you have pain, try simple lifestyle tweaks, home remedies, or alternative modalities that may alleviate your discomfort without medication overuse downsides.
One of my medical students at California University of Sciences & Medicine (CalMed), Garbel Zeynalvand, says:

“Often, our initial thoughts when we’re feeling pain are: 'Why am I feeling this? How can I make this stop?' When we take a moment to process these thoughts, we can explore alternative methods of relief … Ultimately, we can develop a deeper understanding of pain management and align these methods with the alternative path to a healthier lifestyle."

content: These lifestyle changes and natural remedies include:

Anti-inflammatory foods . These are cold-water fish, nuts, olive oil, colorful fruits and vegetables, and green tea. Pineapple and papaya contain enzymes that can help reduce your muscle inflammation.
Heat/ice therapy. Try heat pads, hot baths, and cold packs can help relieve your back strain, arthritis, and headache pain.
Topical ointments. These include menthol, CBD, capsicum, turmeric, arnica, ginger, lavender, and peppermint essential oils that target sore muscles and joints.
Posture support. Lumbar cushions, monitor risers, ergonomic chairs, wrist braces, and massage tools can help prevent body strain.
Stretching, yoga, and massage. These loosen your muscle tension caused by poor ergonomics, athletics, stress, and anxiety.
Stress relief, sleep hygiene, and mental health. These are linked to pain severity. Breathing exercises, meditation, guided imagery, and getting quality sleep can help lessen your pain.
The goal is building long-term pain resilience through natural solutions rather than popping pills for instant relief.
